article.name: Local government areas.
article.text:
- Parliament has the authority to divide Guyana into ten regions and create sub-regions and other subdivisions for local democratic organs.
- When defining the boundaries of these areas, factors such as population, physical size, geographical characteristics, economic resources, and existing/planned infrastructure should be considered.
- The goal is to ensure that each area is economically viable and can effectively manage and utilize its resources and infrastructure.

article.name: Electoral system.
article.text:

- Each elector has one vote and can cast it for any of the lists.

article.title: PARLIAMENT
article.name: Mode of legislation.
article.text:
- The power to make laws in Guyana is exercised by Parliament through Bills passed by the National Assembly and assented to by the President.
- When a Bill is presented to the President for assent, he or she can either assent or withhold assent.
- If the President withholds assent, the Bill is returned to the Speaker within 21 days with a message stating the reasons for withholding assent.
- The Bill cannot be presented to the President again unless the National Assembly resolves, with a two-thirds majority, to present it again within six months.
- If the National Assembly resolves to present the Bill again, it must be presented within 90 days and the President must assent to it.
- A Bill can only become law if it has been duly passed and assented to in accordance with the Constitution.

article.name: Privileges, etc., of members of the National Assembly.
article.text: (1) Subject to the provisions of paragraphs (2), (3) and (4), Parliament may by law determine the privileges, immunities and powers of members of the National Assembly and the members thereof. (2) No civil or criminal proceedings may be instituted against any member of the Assembly for words spoken before, or written in a report to, the Assembly or to a committee thereof or by reason of any matter or thing brought by him or her therein by petition, bill, resolution, motion or otherwise. article.name: Removal of President on grounds of incapacity.
article.text:

article.title: DEFENCE AND SECURITY
article.name: Defence and security.
article.text: The State's defence and security policy aims to defend national independence, preserve sovereignty and integrity, and ensure the security of citizens against armed aggression. The Defence and Security Forces are subordinate to national defence and security policy and are loyal to the Constitution and the Nation. Members of the Defence and Security Forces take an oath to respect the Constitution. The Guyana Defence Force functions in a manner that earns respect and confidence from citizens. The Police Force functions as the law enforcement agency of the State, maintaining law and order by suppressing crime. article.title: THE ETHNIC RELATIONS COMMISSION
article.name: Composition of Ethnic Relations Commission.
article.text: The Ethnic Relations Commission is composed of a minimum of five and a maximum of fifteen members. The members are nominated by entities through a consensual mechanism determined by the National Assembly. The entities that nominate members include religious bodies, the labour movement, the private business sector, youth, and women. The entities are determined by a vote of at least two-thirds of the National Assembly. The functions of the Ethnic Relations Commission are determined by the votes of the entities. If a member's position is vacant or they are unable to perform their duties, someone can be appointed to act in their place. The appointment process for acting members follows the same provisions as the appointment of regular members. Acting members continue to serve until a permanent replacement is appointed and assumes the functions of the office, or until the original holder of the office resumes their duties.

article.text: (1) During the hearing by the disciplinary tribunal, its main purpose is to elicit all such information including documentary proof as in the circumstances may be considered necessary without being bound by the rules of evidence in civil or criminal proceedings provided always that if any witness objects to answering any question or to producing any document on the ground that it will tend to incriminate him or any other lawful ground, he shall not be required to answer such question or to produce such document, nor shall he be liable to any penalties for refusing to do so. article.title: PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION RULES
article.name: Strikes by officers.
article.text:
- Salaries and wages will not be paid to officers who go on strike, except for essential services.
- If an officer reports for work during a strike but does not work, they will not receive pay for that day.
- If an officer works only part of a day during a strike, they will not be paid for the withheld period.

article.name: Inefficiency and minor misconduct, procedures to be allowed.
article.text:

- In aggravated cases, the Commission must be formally informed.
- For minor misconduct, the officer must be notified in writing of the grounds for disciplinary action and given a chance to defend themselves.
- The Secretary to the Commission must provide relevant reports on the matter.
- In other cases, if grounds for disciplinary action are found, the Commission may initiate proceedings.
- After the disciplinary proceedings, if the officer is exonerated, no penalty is imposed.
- If the allegation is proved, the Commission can impose penalties such as a caution, reprimand, or demotion.

article.title: PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION RULES
article.name: Proceedings in serious misconduct cases.
article.text:
- The officer must be notified in writing of the allegations and given the opportunity to defend themselves.
- The Secretary of the Commission must provide a copy of the allegation, the officer's response, and their own report to the Commission.
- If the officer fails to respond or obstructs the process, the Secretary will inform the Commission.
- The Commission may conduct further investigation if necessary.
- The Commission may institute disciplinary proceedings if they are satisfied with the investigation.
- The officer has the right to request to appear before the Commission with representation.
- The officer, their representative, or attorney can be present and question witnesses.
- No documentary evidence can be used against the officer unless they have been provided with a copy or given access to it.
- If the Commission determines the officer should be exonerated, the case will be dismissed.
- If the officer should be dismissed or retired, the Committee will take action.
- If a lesser penalty is appropriate, such as a caution or reprimand, the Commission may impose it.
